posts.name: Chava Schuster
posts.cooked: We are having issues with one of our falcons. The CAM and Power cables are properly connected but it is still alternating red. We have other Falcons as reference, and they all work normally. Since we couldn’t figure out the issue externally, we opened up the Falcon. Then we tried connecting it directly from the CAM to the soldering inside, yet it still showed this issue. We are sure it’s not a programming issue since we have not even started programming yet. Is there a possible fix or other solution?

YellowSponge:

since we have not even started programming yet

Have you tried updating the firmware in Phoenix Tuner? Does this device show up in Phoenix Tuner?

What is the actual operational issue you encounter?

posts.name: Chava Schuster
posts.cooked: It’s the electronics, not the programming.

posts.name: Alex Van Aacken
posts.cooked: Page 44 has the LED codes. It looks like that the red alternating flashes either mean “CAN/PWM is not detected” (slow blink) or just “fault detected” (fast blink)

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Have you checked the LED blink pattern against what youre seeing?

Also, you say you tested the CAN wires against the solder pads inside the controller? You definitely shouldnt need to do this.  Contacting CTRE for support should happen WAY before you start mucking about in the internal electronics.

link_counts.title: Status Light Quick Reference — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Matthew Gallagher
posts.cooked: If your CAN is properly connected it is blinking as a fault, which does not necessarily mean that it is actually a fault, my team had the same issue last year, which ended up being that two motors shared the same id. You can fix this by changing the motor ids in Phoenix Tuner.

posts.name: Newton Crosby Jr
posts.cooked:
If it isn’t a CAN issue, then it’s something to due with the firmware. If you’re still having problems, try factory resetting them, then re-flash the firmware, then reset again. That will completely wipe any possible config issues with that firmware version, load in the latest firmware, then ensure it’s completely blank to start with. If you really want to go overboard, then try a new RIO or PWM. I’d also recommend a PDP check, though power doesn’t seem to be the issue here.

Attack it like a software bug. Eliminate every possible variable, then test one variable in all it’s possible forms. Then erase that and test one different variable in all it’s forms.
